comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Fascinating to see these docks in operation, all the machinery and characters.  That must be the date;  I can't find anything in Trove yet.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: 1899 details of the dock at beginning of work - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14205298 1909 dock extended - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/15037476 1902 details of the floating dock (see note) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14454479 Trying to find out how the caisson or lock-gate worked. Armchair industrial archaeology!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The men having a smoko next to piles of what looks like stone slabs could have been working on quarrying the stone (out of shot to the left) which went on even after the dock was opened. Evidently there was a new stone-cutting machine which had an official visit in May 1900 (more details about the dock) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14312442

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Beachcomber we love that phrase -"Armchair industrial archaeology!". Thanks for all the info, interesting time for the dry dock, it was still so new.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] And re Colin - Christmas is coming up!!!
